concise_definition: v. 欺骗, 戏弄, 玩弄; n. 欺骗行为, 戏弄

definitions.explanation_en: To deceive or trick someone, often in a playful or harmless way, by making them believe something that is not true.
definitions.explanation_cn: 通过让人相信不真实的事情来欺骗或捉弄某人，通常带有玩笑或无害的性质。
definitions.example_en: He was just fooling around—he didn't really mean to upset you.
definitions.example_cn: 他只是在开玩笑，并不是真想惹你生气。

definitions.explanation_en: To behave in a silly or irresponsible manner, often to avoid seriousness or responsibility.
definitions.explanation_cn: 以愚蠢或不负责任的方式行事，常为逃避严肃性或责任。
definitions.example_en: Stop fooling around and focus on your homework!
definitions.example_cn: 别再胡闹了，专心写作业！

definitions.explanation_en: An act of deception or playful trickery; a prank or joke intended to mislead someone.
definitions.explanation_cn: 一种欺骗行为或玩笑式的捉弄，旨在误导他人。
definitions.example_en: That prank was just a harmless fooling—no one was really hurt.
definitions.example_cn: 那个恶作剧只是无害的戏弄，没人真的受伤。

comparison.analysis: “Deceiving”（欺骗）更正式、更严肃，通常带有恶意或意图获取利益，强调系统性或长期的误导。而 “fooling” 更常用于日常语境，多指临时、轻度甚至幽默的欺骗，情感色彩较轻。
“Tricking”（设圈套）与 “fooling” 接近，但更强调通过精心设计的手段使人上当，常含策略性。而 “fooling” 更随意，可能只是言语或行为上的玩笑，不一定有预谋。
“Mocking”（嘲弄）侧重于通过讽刺、嘲笑来贬低或羞辱他人，情感上更具攻击性。而 “fooling” 通常不以伤害为目的，有时甚至带有亲密或调侃的意味。
